description: Students explore how family relationships are influenced by social, historical, and political
contexts. Drawing on a range of disciplinary contexts and research, this course underscores the
ways family relationships are constructed, sustained and challenged in society, with emphasis on
theories and practice of family communication. Students draw on the relational dynamics studied in
the introductory family studies course to transition to elaborating on the complexities of family
functioning in U.S. society and beyond.   Offered each semester. Also counts toward
gender and sexuality studies major and educational studies and gender and sexuality studies
